**Even cards:** Queen of Spades (1), 6 of Spades (2), 6 of Hearts (3), 2 of Clubs (6), Jack of Diamonds (7)

- Actually wait, I have 4 clubs: Ace, 7, 2, 3 - that's a flush potential!

- Ace of Clubs (4)

- 3 of Diamonds (8) - not a club

So I have 3 clubs, not 4. Not a flush.

Let me think about the best play:

**Option 1: Use The Hierophant on 2 odd cards, then play a hand with those cards**

If I use The Hierophant on Ace of Clubs and 7 of Clubs, they become Bonus Cards worth +30 chips each, giving me 41 and 37 chips respectively instead of their base values.

With Odd Todd adding +31 to each odd card, the Ace jumps to 72 chips and the 7 to 68. Playing those two plus the 3 of Diamonds creates a High Card hand where only the Ace contributes—that's 5 base chips plus 41 from the enhanced Ace, totaling 46, then another +31 from Odd Todd.

That gives me just 77 chips, nowhere near the 450 I need. Using The Hierophant on the pair of 6s instead would make each worth 36 chips, creating a pair worth 164 chips after the 2x multiplier—still insufficient. I should reconsider what hand combinations are actually available to me. the Ace counts toward the hand
- Base chips: 1
- Card chips: 36 (Ace enhanced) + 7 (7 not enhanced) + 3 (3 not enhanced) = 46
- Total chips: 1 + 46 = 47
- Multiplier: 1
- Total: 47 chips

But wait, Odd Todd triggers on odd-ranked cards. The Ace, 7, and 3 are all odd. So I'd get +31 chips for each of them when they're scored as part of the hand. That means:
- Base hand chips: 1
- Card chips: 36 + 7 + 3 = 46
- Odd Todd bonus: 31 × 3 = 93
- Total: 1 + 46 + 93 = 140 chips
- Multiplier: 1
- Total: 140 chips

That's much better than the pair of 6s approach. The key insight is that Odd Todd gives a flat +31 per odd card in the scoring hand, regardless of whether they're enhanced or not. Pair of 6s (2, 3) in hand with Queen, Ace, 7, 2, Jack, 3. I could discard to build Two Pair, or use The Hierophant on the 6s with odd cards. But I need to reconsider the scoring rules—only cards that are part of the highest hand contribute their chip values. So if I play a pair of 6s with three odd cards, only the pair scores chips, not the individual cards. The Odd Todd effect still applies to odd-ranked cards in the scoring hand though.

This means I should either construct a hand made entirely of odd cards to maximize Odd Todd's bonus, or focus on enhancing cards that will actually contribute to the final hand. A hand of Ace, 7, and 3 would be all odd cards but only make a High Card. I could also try discarding to gather more odd cards. The Hierophant might be better used to strengthen a hand that will actually score, rather than padding it with non-contributing cards.

With 4 hands and 3 discards remaining, I need 450 chips total. A Full House of all odd cards would give me 242 base chips (40 hand + 47 card chips + 155 from Odd Todd), which multiplies to 968 with a 4x multiplier—easily exceeding my target. The challenge is I don't currently have that combination. I should focus on what's actually achievable: enhancing my pair of 6s into Bonus Cards and pairing them with odd cards that will count toward the hand.

Before committing to a play, I could use my remaining discards strategically. Keeping the pair of 6s plus my odd cards (Ace, 7, 3) while discarding the Queen, 2, and Jack might improve my odds. Alternatively, I could apply The Hierophant to boost specific cards—enhancing the Ace and 7 would push them to 41 and 37 chips respectively, giving me more flexibility in forming a stronger hand.

I'll go ahead and use The Hierophant on the Ace of Clubs and 7 of Clubs to maximize their contribution.

Let me calculate the scoring for different options:

**Option 1: Play Pair of 6s + 3 odd cards (Ace, 7, 3)**
Hand type: Pair
- Base hand chips: 10
- Base mult: 2
- Cards that participate in the pair: 6 of Spades and 6 of Hearts
- Card chips from the pair: 6 + 6 = 12
- Odd Todd bonus: The pair consists of even cards, so no bonus from Odd Todd for the pair itself
- Total chips: 10 + 12 = 22


- Total mult: 2
- Final chips: 22 × 2 = 44 chips

This is far too low. I need to reconsider my approach. In a pair, only the cards forming the pair contribute their chip values, and Odd Todd only triggers on odd-ranked cards that are actually scored. Since the 6s are even, they won't activate the joker bonus.

**Option 2: Play all 3 odd cards (Ace, 7, 3) as a High Card instead** would let me leverage Odd Todd's +31 chips per odd card, giving me 93 chips from the joker alone plus the base card values.

But I'm still getting suboptimal results. The real constraint is that only scored cards trigger Odd Todd, and I need to figure out which hand type maximizes the number of odd cards that actually get scored. A pair only scores two cards, while a high card scores just one. I should explore whether there's a way to score more odd cards simultaneously. cards to play. If I select positions 4 and 5 (the pair of 6s), only those two contribute chips—the other cards I pick don't add value unless they're part of the actual hand. So if I play the Ace, 7, and 3 alongside the pair, they won't score because they're not participating in the pair itself.

My realistic options are to either play the pair now and accept the modest payout, or discard some cards hoping to improve. Discarding the Queen, Jack, and 2 would let me keep the odd-ranked cards and 6s while drawing fresh cards. I need to figure out whether the expected value of a better hand justifies the risk of discarding.

A two pair would be significantly stronger—20 base chips with 2x multiplier, plus the card values from both pairs. If I could pair my 7s with the Bonus 7 I have, that would trigger Odd Todd for additional chips per odd card. Let me work through the math: two pair gives 20 base, the 6s contribute 12 chips, and if the 7s are paired with my Bonus 7, each 7 would be worth around 37 chips with the bonus factored in, giving me roughly 106 total chips before Odd Todd multiplies the odd cards further.

Even accounting for Odd Todd's bonus on the 7s, I'm looking at around 168 chips with a 2x multiplier, which only gets me to 336—still short of 450. I need to consider other hand types like a flush or straight, or possibly three of a kind. Actually, the simplest move is to discard strategically and redraw. I'll hold onto my enhanced odd cards and the pair of 6s, letting go of the Queen, 2, and Jack to find better cards. Though I should reconsider—the 3 is odd too, so keeping it would help with Odd Todd's payout.

# Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
play <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Play the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may play up to 5 cards at a time. If you play a hand, you must also respond with the intended hand type you think you are playing, and an estimate of the number of chips you think you will earn from the hand. Use the results of previous hands played to inform your estimate.
discard <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Discard the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may discard up to 5 cards at a time.
rearrange_hand <card1> <card2> ... <cardN> - Rearrange the hand of cards. Every index in the list of current cards must be present, i.e. if there are 5 cards, the indices 1-5 must be present.
